nodes.text: Probability weighting observed in experiments (inverse-S mapping between decision-weight CDF Fw and probability CDF Fp) can be explained mechanistically by differences between models used by a disinterested observer and a decision maker, rather than requiring a cognitive bias

Context: probability weighting is the empirical observation from prospect theory that inferred decision weights exceed declared probabilities for rare events and are lower for common events, producing an inverse-S when plotting Fw against Fp

Claim: the inverse-S arises whenever the decision maker assumes a larger scale (greater dispersion) or different location for the distribution of outcomes than the observer, even when both use unimodal distributions

Claim: disagreement between DO and DM models is common and tends to be systematic with DMs assuming a greater range of plausible outcomes due to limited information and the need to estimate probabilities from finite time series

Context/Assumption: probabilities can be interpreted as ensemble frequencies, time-series frequencies, or degrees of belief, and mismatches in interpretation contribute to model differences between DO and DM

Method: analytical mapping for Gaussian case where DO uses p(x)=Normal(mu,sigma) and DM uses w(x)=Normal(mu,alpha*sigma), leading to explicit relation w(p)=p^(1/alpha^2) times a normalization prefactor
Claim: the inverse-S also arises for other distribution shapes (e.g., t-distributions) when DM assumes greater scale or different shape parameters than DO

Claim: when probabilities are estimated from finite time series, absolute estimation error for low-probability events is small but relative error is large, so rarer events have larger relative uncertainty
Result/Evidence: plotting CDF mappings for Gaussian and t-distributions with differing scale/location reproduces the inverse-S shape visually similar to experimental data

Claim: a decision maker aware of estimation uncertainty will conservatively adjust estimated probabilities upward by an uncertainty term (e.g., add standard error) before normalizing, forming decision weights w(x)

Method/Evidence: formalisation and simulation where DM sets w(x) proportional to estimated p(x) plus its standard error, with analytic scaling arguments and numerical simulations showing this produces inverse-S mappings for Gaussian and fat-tailed references

Result: fitted Gaussian and t-distribution model parameters (location and scale/shape differences) produce fits to Tversky and Kahneman (1992) and Tversky and Fox (1995) data that are statistically comparable to established phenomenological weighting functions

Claim: differences in perspective (ensemble view of DO vs time-evolution view of DM) and non-ergodicity of wealth processes motivate DMs to hedge against rare adverse events, explaining systematic cautious adjustments

Conclusion: the inverse-S pattern is a neutral indicator of model disagreement and can be interpreted as a principled, mechanistic response to uncertainty by DMs rather than necessarily a cognitive bias

Limitation: the mechanistic model depends on assumptions about how DMs estimate probabilities (e.g., adding standard error) and on the specifics of finite sample estimation and distributional forms, which may vary across contexts
